utterances: Among other things, Yahoo!
is doing this - is what's called an auto-opt-in service.
So you basically have no way of opting out of this.
You're not even necessarily aware that it's being done.
So what are some things that can be learned about me just as I surf the Web?
Someone can learn my name, I suppose.
What else?
Well, it's interesting.
You leave different kinds of traces in different places.

So you might use something like the Nike+iPod Sport kit, which is a sneaker that has an RF ID, a radio frequency identification tag in it, that uploads information about your running times and the calories that you've burned and how far you've run.
And that gives you a sort of an indication as to your likely health status.
This is information that's out there, then, that marketers can grab on to.
Well, theoretically.

What we have to do is imagine an environment in the very short term in which all sorts of information is not merely present in these, sort of, discrete silos, but can't be unified in real time into - I don't know whether or not it will be an accurate picture, but a very detailed picture of high-level behavioral patterns, what my social networks are, what my potential affinities are, what my health is.
And obviously, you can do a lot more than just serve ads based on that.
What's to stop people from opting out the old-fashioned way?
Just turn off the computer?
Not a thing.
The value proposition is fairly clearly the one of convenience, that we will stop bombarding you with ads that are irrelevant to you.
And instead, we will target you ads that actually, you know, reflect your choices and your existence on this planet.
And I have to think that that's going to be fairly seductive for some people.
You know, I myself have a little WiGID in my Web browser that blocks the ads at all to begin with, which is definitely a counter measure that people can take.
But that requires just a touch more technical sophistication and effort than a great many users are going to be bothered with.
Oh, so if you know what you're doing, you can go non-commercial?
Oh, absolutely.
It's wonderful.
If you go to Yahoo!
on your computer, what do you see where I see this Nordstrom ad?
I would probably see a white box.
Oh.
But Iâ€¦
Oh, or you're missing the spectacular fall fashions.
Hey, I guess, I have - I won't be (unintelligible) this fall.
Well, Adam Greenfield, thanks very much for speaking with us.
Thanks, Steve.
He's author of ""Everyware: The Dawning Age of Ubiquitous Computing.
NPR's business news starts with private equity moving into hotels.
(Soundbite of music)
Blackstone has announced it's acquiring Hilton Hotels, the second largest U.S.
hotel chain after Marriott.
The firm will pay $20 billion to gain control over one of the most prominent hotel names in the country.
Blackstone, a private equity group that buys out other companies, went public almost three weeks ago.
It was one of Wall Street's most anticipated offerings in years.
But Blackstone share price fell sharply soon after it started trading, disappointing investors.
From the window of her new home in Long Beach, Mississippi, Tonya Walker had a postcard view of the Gulf of Mexico.
She moved there just a few weeks ago.
Now she's among the missing.
As Hurricane Katrina approached last Sunday, her mother, Betty Higgins, called from Florida to see how Tonya was doing.
Betty Higgins says her daughter moved to Mississippi to work on a boat off the Gulf Coast.
It was a ship that the oil rig workers or the oil workers came on and slept.
It was on the Mississippi River.
And she was what you call a maid, I guess, because she took care of the staterooms and all.
She just told me she was running up 12 flights of stairs 10 or 15 times a day.
Her daughter, says Betty Higgins, was trying to save money and make a fresh start.
Well, she has six children, and she had a drinking problem when she lived in Tampa, and I think she thought if she moved away from the environment, she was would get it under control, which she did.
When her mother spoke to her, Tonya was trying to prepare her new home for the approaching storm.
When I talked to her on Sunday, I was begging her to leave.
She said, `Mom, I have no way.
She said, `I've got the storm shutters up and I'm going to try to stay here.
And, you know--and I'm saying, `If you have to walk, please leave.
She said, `Mom, I have no way, and they've closed everything.'
But the next time Tonya called, it was clear she was in trouble.
She said the floodwaters were spilling over the floor.
That's when the phone went dead.
From what her mom has seen on television, nothing is left on that stretch of beach where her daughter lived and where Tonya had asked her mother to call on her 42nd birthday.
Betty Higgins remembers their last conversation.
P.J.
Rice Bistro in the Westfield Shopping Mall.
Right.
I mean that's, you know, that's not where you would have imagined an alleged drug kingpin of his stature.
So Ernesto, what happens next?
Do you think that Ye Gon will stay in the U.S.
or will he be sent back to Mexico?
Yes.
It came from listener Carol Highland of Ephrata, Washington.
I said take the brand name of a popular grocery item, written normally in upper- and lower-case letters.
I said push two consecutive letters without otherwise changing the name in any way, and the result will name a make of car.
What is it?
Well, the answer is Mazola, as in the margarine or vegetable oil.
And if you push the O and the L together, you get the D, which creates the name Mazda, the car.
We got an interesting alternative answer.
A listener sent in Lipton, as in tea.
If you squish the L and I together, it sort of makes a U.
And there is an old make of car, the Upton.
It's been defunct since 1907, but I give that listener high credit.
Wow.
Points for knowing your history.
But nevertheless, our randomly selected winner this week is Keith Gurland of Holmes, New York.
He joins us on the line now.
Hey, Keith.
Hey, there.
Congratulations.
Thank you.
So, what's going on in Holmes?
What do you do in Holmes, New York?
Well, I'm a freelance saxophone player, so I drive to and from Holmes quite a bit.
Do you drive a Mazda, perchance?
I do not, although there is one in the family.
(LAUGHTER)
So, Keith, freelance saxophonist from Holmes, New York, are you ready to play the puzzle?
Yes.
Yes.
Good answer.
Good answer.
OK, Will, let's do it.
All right, Keith and Rachel.
I'm going to name some geographical places.
For each one, change one letter to make a new common uncapitalized word that has a different number of syllables as the geographical name.
For example, if I said Lima L-I-M-A, you might say limp L-I-M-P, changing the A to a P, and Lima, of course, has two syllables; limp has one.
You might also have said limb or lime.
Some of the names have multiple answers.
OK.
All right.
Here's number one: Peru P-E-R-U.
Well, perp.
Perp is good.
Perk or pert - any of those.
Number two is Iran.
Iran.
